item.title: Selenium To Soup To Pandas
item.dc:creator: Cloistered Monkey
item.description:
Pandas has a read_html function that will automatically convert HTML tables that it finds into DataFrames, but if you need to do a little cleaning up of the tables first or are doing some exploration of the HTML it can be useful to work with it in Beautiful Soup first, and if the table is being rendered on the page with Javascript it can be useful to use Selenium to grab the page for you so that it's rendered.

Start selenium (headless) and grab the page.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

Give it to Beautiful Soup.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

Do stuff with the soup (not shown).

Optionally grab the table you want - in this case I want the last one.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

But if there's one or you just want the first one you could use find instead.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

Pass it to pandas.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

tables is a list of DataFrames - one for each table that pandas found - even if there's only one so now it might be useful to get the one you want.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

From what I understand from the documentation, pandas is using Beautiful Soup to parse the HTML, so if the tables come out okay and you don't need to mess around with the HTML tree beforehand you can just skip the soup.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

item.title: Pandas String Replacement With a Callback
item.dc:creator: Cloistered Monkey
item.description:
If you want to replace parts of strings in a Pandas Series you can pass in a string, but if you want to keep part of the original sub-string that you are replacing you can call the replace method while passing in a function that un-packs the match object.

As an example, to add paretheses around strings that look like "Also see penguin" you can define a regular expression that has a named group in it.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

Then define a function that expects objects that match the pattern and creates a string using the named-group.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

Then pass in the pattern and function to the replace method.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

item.title: XML To Pandas
item.dc:creator: Cloistered Monkey
item.description:
Table of Contents

  • Beginning
    • Imports
    • Set Up
  • Middle
    • The XML
    • To a DataFrame
    • Save It
  • End
    • Time Series

Beginning

I went to the Social Security website to change my password (I had forgotten it so they mailed a temporary one to me) and noticed that they have your yearly reported earnings both as a PDF and as a data download. Unfortunately the data is given as an XML file instead of a CSV (it has more than just the earnings data, so it would have to be a series of CSVs instead of one file) so these are my notes on converting it to a pandas DataFrame using BeautifulSoup.

Imports

To actually do the conversion you only need BeautifulSoup and pandas, all the rest of the stuff comes into play because I'm making a post.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

Set Up

The Dotenv

I'm using a .env file to point to the location of the file so this call will load it.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

The Plotting

This is just a central place to set up some constants so I don't have to re-type them or hunt around for them if I want to change things.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

The Random Seed

I decided since I'm talking about social security stuff I'd make at least some attempt at obfuscating things so I'm adding a random offset to the years.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

Middle

The XML

Loading It

First, I'll load the XML into BeautifulSoup.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

Note that you have to pass in the "xml" argument - BeautifulSoup is primarily an HTML parser so it assumes an HTML document by default. Normally I'd do some exploring at this point, but I didn't find it such an easy thing to do (I don't work with XML data generally) and found that it was easier to look at it with less and figure out what I needed.

The Earnings

The data I wanted is in a set of tags that look like this:

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

This set represents what was collected in 1998 - $526 for Social Security and Medicare (FICA stands for Federal Insurance Contributions Act and is the name of the tax that funds Social Security). Yes, I only made $526 in 1998 because I was a teenager working a part-time job taking store inventories - still, I can't believe how little I got paidâ¦

Anyway, so the first thing to do is to grab all the nodes representing earning.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments' 
34
<osss:Earnings endYear="1998" startYear="1998">
<osss:FicaEarnings>526</osss:FicaEarnings>
<osss:MedicareEarnings>526</osss:MedicareEarnings>
</osss:Earnings>

The Years

Now that we have the earnings, we can see about getting the years. Although they have endYear and startYear they're always the same so I'll use startYear. I'm adding the OFFSET here just to obfuscate what years I'm looking at.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments' 
1998
1999
2000
2001
2002

Collected

Next I'll see about grabbing the amounts collected for each year. The FICA and Medicare amounts are always the same so I'll just use the FICA amount.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments' 
526
1123
1546
0
0

That looks right. It drops to 0 because I went to college and started working on campus and since I went to a state university they didn't collect FICA.

To a DataFrame

Anyway, that's basically all you need to get it going.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments' 
   offset  amount
0    1998     526
1    1999    1123
2    2000    1546
3    2001       0
4    2002       0

Save It

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

End

I usually like to put in a little plotting so I'm going to plot the amount over time. Since I already shared my first five years I'm going to start after that and obscure the numbers a little.

Time Series

First I'll add the offset year back in, then I'm going to scale it.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments' Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments' Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

Well, there you go. Since I'm adding a random offset to the years I removed the x-axis labels, but the plot starts out with me still working for the State, so there's no reported income, then there's an uptick when I took a retail job, then a drop again when I went back to school for a little while to look into getting a design degree, then there's another uptick when I gave up on the design degree and went to work as a clerk for a real estate office, then the next drop comes when I went back to get a Computer Science degree and the rising after that shows the difference between working retail/clerical versus being a computer programmer, with the two plateaus representing the two companies I've worked for.

item.title: Categorical Plotting
item.dc:creator: Cloistered Monkey
item.description:
Table of Contents

  • Imports
  • Set Up
  • The Data
  • Grouping
  • Concatenate our data
  • Scaled

Imports

From Python

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

From pypi

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

Set Up

The Plotting

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

The Tables

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

The Data

This is just some fake stuff to test it out. We're going to simulate how participants in a survey scored two products on a scale from -3 to 3.

Product One

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments' Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'
country Alpha -3 Alpha -2 Alpha -1 Alpha 0 Alpha 1 Alpha 2 Alpha 3
china 0 0 0 0 0 0 1
china 0 0 0 1 0 0 0
china 1 0 0 0 0 0 0
china 0 1 0 0 0 0 0
china 0 0 0 1 0 0 0

Product Two

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments' Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'
country Beta -3 Beta -2 Beta -1 Beta 0 Beta 1 Beta 2 Beta 3
china 0 0 0 1 0 0 0
china 0 0 0 0 0 0 1
china 0 1 0 0 0 0 0
china 0 0 0 1 0 0 0
china 1 0 0 0 0 0 0

Grouping

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments' Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'
country Alpha -3 Alpha -2 Alpha -1 Alpha 0 Alpha 1 Alpha 2 Alpha 3
china 6 8 3 9 4 11 9
india 3 3 3 3 4 1 3
japan 0 0 1 0 0 0 1
Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments' Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'
country Beta -3 Beta -2 Beta -1 Beta 0 Beta 1 Beta 2 Beta 3
china 1 5 4 2 3 1 4
india 5 2 10 2 3 4 4
japan 5 4 2 3 3 5 3
Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

Concatenate our data

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

Scaled

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'
country Alpha -3 Alpha -2 Alpha -1 Alpha 0 Alpha 1 Alpha 2 Alpha 3
china 0.12 0.16 0.06 0.18 0.08 0.22 0.18
india 0.15 0.15 0.15 0.15 0.2 0.05 0.15
japan 0 0 0.5 0 0 0 0.5
Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'
country Beta -3 Beta -2 Beta -1 Beta 0 Beta 1 Beta 2 Beta 3
china 0.05 0.25 0.2 0.1 0.15 0.05 0.2
india 0.166667 0.0666667 0.333333 0.0666667 0.1 0.133333 0.133333
japan 0.2 0.16 0.08 0.12 0.12 0.2 0.12
Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

Well, I guess I need to work on making the reds visible, but I'm out of time.

item.title: Date Mean Squared Error
item.dc:creator: Cloistered Monkey
item.description:
Table of Contents

  • What is this?
  • Imports
  • The Data
  • The Mean
  • Getting the Mean Back Into the Frame
  • Calculating the RMSE

What is this?

This is a short sketch to figure out how to group a bunch of values by month and calculate the Root-Mean-Squared-Error (RMSE) for the mean for the values in that month. This probably isn't the most efficient way to do this, but I'm trying to double check everything as I go and doing the typical Train Wreck like you see in most examples on Stack Overflow.

Imports

From PyPi

Just pandas.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

The Data

I'm going to create some simple values so that it's easy(ish) to do the math by hand and double-check what comes out. I'll use the pandas Timestamp for the dates. I'm still not one-hundred percent sure why it's better than date-time, but hopefully it's optimized or something.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

I'm going to use pandas' resample method to group the data by months. the resample method expets the data to have the dates as the index, so I'm going to create a new frame by setting the index to the date-column.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments'

The Mean

The value I'm going to use to estimate the values for each month is the mean.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments' 
            value
date             
2018-09-30    2.0
2018-10-31    1.5

Getting the Mean Back Into the Frame

Now that we have the monthly means, I want to re-add them to the original data-frame by giving them a common column named year_month (using apply) so I can broadcast the means by merging the two data-frames.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments' 
        date  value year_month
0 2018-09-01      1 2018-09-01
1 2018-09-05      2 2018-09-01
2 2018-09-05      3 2018-09-01
3 2018-10-01      1 2018-10-01
4 2018-10-05      2 2018-10-01
Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments' 
        date  value year_month
0 2018-09-30    2.0 2018-09-01
1 2018-10-31    1.5 2018-10-01

The value column in the mean_frame is actually the mean of the values for that month so I'll re-name it before I forget.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments' 
        date  mean year_month
0 2018-09-30   2.0 2018-09-01
1 2018-10-31   1.5 2018-10-01

Now I'll merge the two data frames on the year_month column using the default inner-join (intersection) method.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments' 
        date  value year_month  mean
0 2018-09-01      1 2018-09-01   2.0
1 2018-09-05      2 2018-09-01   2.0
2 2018-09-05      3 2018-09-01   2.0
3 2018-10-01      1 2018-10-01   1.5
4 2018-10-05      2 2018-10-01   1.5

Note that I had to use the merged["mean"] form because the data-frame has a mean method which the dot-notation (merged.mean) would call instead of grabbing the column.

Calculating the RMSE

Error

Since I'm estimating the values for each month using the mean the error is the difference between the mean and each of the values.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments' 
        date  value year_month  mean  error
0 2018-09-01      1 2018-09-01   2.0   -1.0
1 2018-09-05      2 2018-09-01   2.0    0.0
2 2018-09-05      3 2018-09-01   2.0    1.0
3 2018-10-01      1 2018-10-01   1.5   -0.5
4 2018-10-05      2 2018-10-01   1.5    0.5

Error Squared

Now I'll square the error to get rid of the negative error values (which would cancel each other out when we take the mean errors) and to make the effect of the errors non-linear (the errors are exagerrated).

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments' Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments' 
        date  value year_month  mean  error  error_squared
0 2018-09-01      1 2018-09-01   2.0   -1.0           1.00
1 2018-09-05      2 2018-09-01   2.0    0.0           0.00
2 2018-09-05      3 2018-09-01   2.0    1.0           1.00
3 2018-10-01      1 2018-10-01   1.5   -0.5           0.25
4 2018-10-05      2 2018-10-01   1.5    0.5           0.25

Mean Squared Error

So now we take the mean of our squared errors to get an initial estimate of how much we are off each month.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments' 
year_month
2018-09-01    0.666667
2018-10-01    0.250000
Name: error_squared, dtype: float64

RMSE

Since the squared error would have units squared, I'll take the root of it to get a more interpretable estimate of the error.

Traceback (most recent call last): File "/home/hades/.local/bin/pygmentize", line 5, in from pygments.cmdline import main ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pygments' 
year_month
2018-09-01    0.816497
2018-10-01    0.500000
Name: error_squared, dtype: float64
